questions.question: What is the maximum speed of 802.11b?
questions.explanation: 802.11b operates at 2.4 GHz with a maximum speed of 11 Mbps.

questions.question: What is the maximum speed of 802.11g?
questions.explanation: 802.11g operates at 2.4 GHz with a maximum speed of 54 Mbps.

questions.question: What is the maximum speed of 802.11a?
questions.explanation: 802.11a operates at 5 GHz with a maximum speed of 54 Mbps.

questions.question: What mode allows devices to communicate directly without an access point?
questions.explanation: Ad hoc mode enables direct device-to-device wireless communication.

questions.question: What mode uses an access point to connect wireless devices?
questions.explanation: Infrastructure mode requires an access point to coordinate wireless devices.

questions.question: Which 802.11 standard supports both 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz?
questions.explanation: 802.11n can operate on both frequency bands for flexibility.

questions.question: What technique uses multiple antennas to improve performance?
questions.explanation: MIMO uses multiple antennas to increase throughput and range.

questions.question: What is 802.11ac also known as?
questions.explanation: 802.11ac is marketed as WiFi 5 and operates primarily on 5 GHz.

questions.question: What is 802.11ax also known as?
questions.explanation: 802.11ax is marketed as WiFi 6, offering improved efficiency and speed.

questions.question: What allows devices to move between access points seamlessly?
questions.explanation: Roaming enables continuous connectivity as devices move between access point coverage areas.
